user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of deinit_data:
```c
static void
deinit_data (void)
{
  if (NULL != resp_single)
    MHD_destroy_response (resp_single);
  resp_single = NULL;
  if (NULL != resps)
  {
    unsigned int i;
    for (i = 0; i < num_resps; ++i)
      MHD_destroy_response (resps[i]);
    num_resps = 0;
    free (resps);
  }
  resps = NULL;
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    free (body_dyn);
  body_dyn = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (NULL != body_dyn)
    free (body_dyn);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this fragment: freeing dynamically allocated memory via a non-const pointer is appropriate. The rule (8.13) concerns pointer declarations (they should be const-qualified where possible), but the shown code only calls free(body_dyn) and then NULLs it — this does not itself violate 8.13. A true violation would be if the pointer was declared non-const even though it only ever points to immutable data (it should have been declared as pointer-to-const), or conversely if body_dyn were declared const and then freed by casting away const (which would introduce other MISRA violations).
